texts.definition: Representation of how likely diegetic agents are to succeed with a type of activity that can be improved through experience.
markups: <style="Definition">Representation of how likely diegetic agents are to succeed with a type of activity that can be improved through experience.</style>

Not everyone is equally good at everything, and this can be explicit represented in games through the use of <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style>. These may be simple labels to indicate who can perform the activity and who cannot, but it is quite common to uses numerical values to <style="CurrentLink">Skill</style> levels and thereby indicate how good characters or units are compared to other diegetic agents. These <style="CurrentLink">Skill</style> values can be used directly to determine success or failure - very often through comparing it to a random number - but can also give players strong hints on the likelihood of success or failure before the actions associated with the skills are actually done.

Many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style>, including <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Basic%20Roleplaying">Basic Roleplaying</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Cthulhu">Call of Cthulhu</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Roleplay">Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Darkness">World of Darkness</link></style> series make use of <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> in some cases extensively so with more than hundred different <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> available. This is echoed in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-based Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>. In some cases, including more action-oriented games, the skills are represented as development trees; examples of this can be found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Borderlands">Borderlands</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dead%20Island">Dead Island</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bloodbowl">Bloodbowl</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Talisman">Talisman</link></style> are examples of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> that make use of <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> as well (even if the values in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Talisman">Talisman</link></style> could be considered attributes).

<style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> are typically used in games to provide ranges in competence regarding <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, allow <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>, explain <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, and create <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style> for diegetic entities such as <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. Areas which need to be considered when designing <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> for use in games include: which <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> exist and how do they concretely influence gameplay, do they contain additional information specific to each diegetic agent possessing the <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style>, and can they be acquired or their <style="CurrentLink">Skill</style> levels can change during gameplay. <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> can either be used directly to see if actions are successful or not but typically <style="Link"><link="dice">Dice</link></style> are used to create possibilities of success and failure depending on <style="CurrentLink">Skill</style> levels; when diegetic <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> use <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> that influence each other this is most often solved through determining the success and failure of each and letting the relative different determine the overall effect. Additional unpredictability regarding results can be achieved through <style="Link"><link="open-ended-die-rolls">Open-Ended Die Rolls</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="critical-results">Critical Results</link></style> (either through <style="Link"><link="critical-failures">Critical Failures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="critical-successes">Critical Successes</link></style>, or both) whenever <style="Link"><link="dice">Dice</link></style> are used. <style="CurrentLink">Skill</style> levels typical affect the probabilities of <style="Link"><link="critical-results">Critical Results</link></style> however, so the patterns can modulate each other.

The number of <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> that make sense in a game naturally depends on the scope of the game and the level of detail wanted. Some games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Talisman">Talisman</link></style>, make due with very few <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> but other games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> have hundreds of skills (especially when they instantiate <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>) and this can create <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Skill-based</style> actions can either have dynamic or static evaluation. Static evaluation promotes <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> but may ruin the <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>  if players can notice exactly what is possible and what is not. Dynamic evaluation usually contains some form of <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> and thereby gives players the chance to have <style="Link"><link="luck">Luck</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> usually let the success or failure depend on how players performs action but let <style="CurrentLink">Skill</style> levels affect the difficulty (i.e. by creating <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style>) or by allowing <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>. Supporting <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> actions is an example of the former and is used in the game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Borderlands">Borderlands</link></style>. For <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style>, it is more common for success or failure to depend entirely on <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style>, although <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> often modify the difficulty depending on how the players have planned to perform the actions.

The simplest forms of Skills, e.g. used in Bloodbowl are labels that signify access to Privileged Abilities or Performance Modifiers such as numerical bonuses. Slightly more complex is providing numerical attributes to how good or bad one is with each Skill, something that can be an Attribute in itself (e.g. Call of Cthulhu or Fallen Reich) or be a relative value linked to other Attributes (e.g. GURPS). Additional details (basically Performance Modifiers) can be added by providing bonuses within specialties and giving penalties if one does not have the appropriate familiarities with specific contexts (both these exist in GURPS); quite naturally, including such details make for Complex Gameplay. Regardless, Skills quite often affect Combat if both patterns are present in a game and likewise the chance of Critical Hits or Critical Misses if these exist are typically affected by Skill levels (e.g. Hârnmaster). For games with Variable Accuracy, Skills can improve this to make players more likely to hit where they aim. Other examples of how Skills can affect gameplay is to allow Crafting, permit the use of specific Controllers or Tools, and affect how well Health can be restored through healing.

Being able to choose which <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> one should have and what levels one should have in these is a common feature for systems that support <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style>. Games supporting this often do this through some form of <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style>, which may be used also for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Advantages">Advantages</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disadvantages">Disadvantages</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>.

Being able to raise or get Skills during gameplay is a common form of Character Development which might also include New Abilities. Freedom of Choice can affect Skills if players have several different Skills they can select from when raising them, and this can make players set up Gain Competence goals in advance as well as lets them have Player-Planned Development. If the Skills as represented as numerical values, this makes it easy to implement both Improved and Decreased Abilities by simply adjusting the values. The causes of Skill increased as simply be completions of challenges, advances in Character Levels, or the result of Investments of Experience Points (but it can also work the other way around - in the Elder Scrolls series a number of Skill points need to be gained to reach a new Character Level). Sometimes these require the presences of Non-Player Characters or Self-Service Kiosks that represent teachers. Skill increase can be modulated by Diminishing Returns, either by requiring more Investments to be done (e.g. GURPS or by making the chances of improving Skills lower the higher the Skills gets (e.g. Basic Roleplaying and its decedents Hârnmaster and Mutant). The complexity of improving Skills can be increased by requiring prerequisites, typically related to other Skills or Attributes or progressing through Development Trees but is sometimes also linked to what Social Organizations one belongs to. Complexity can also be added by allowing for the above mentioned specialties and familiarities. In addition to making permanent changes, Buffs, Debuffs, Damage, and Tools can all be used to create temporary Performance Modifiers for Skills; that can be used to create Critical Hits to Damage effects that otherwise would just reduce Health. Roleplaying Games striving for realism quite often give Decreased Abilities to Skills for those that make use of powerful Armor.

As a minor point, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> making use of <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> may require <style="Link"><link="bookkeeping-tokens">Bookkeeping Tokens</link></style> to keep track of their numerical values.

<style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> do not in themselves relate to narrative aspects of games, but the <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> increases in <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> can represent can be seen as a form of <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>. In cases where the outcome of <style="CurrentLink">Skill</style> tests would be problematic for the game narration, e.g. causing <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style>, games with <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> can avoid this by the <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> resorting to <style="Link"><link="feigned-die-rolls">Feigned Die Rolls</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> are a form of <style="Link"><link="characteristics">Characteristics</link></style> (often <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style>) describing how well one can perform activities that at least diegetically can be improved through training. This provides one way of differentiating <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> and thereby giving players <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>. It also gives players a solid foundation for having a <style="Link"><link="determinable-chance-succeed">Determinable Chance to Succeed</link></style> with the activities linked to the specific <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style>. Increases of <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> are typically <style="Link"><link="facilitating-rewards">Facilitating Rewards</link></style>.

When <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> are used to create <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, it promotes <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> and being able to choose what <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> to improve in a game can be seen as a form of <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style> in related to <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>. Given that <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> represent chances of succeeding with activities, the use of them can affect how well players can perceive <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> from their intended actions. The possibility to increase <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> is one way in which games can provide players with <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style> goals. <style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> can naturally also be used to create differences in <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> in addition to doing so in player-controlled entities, and limit the usefulness of <style="Link"><link="mules">Mules</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Skills</style> that directly affect how well players can perform physical actions, e.g. aiming in <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> activities, give rise to <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style>. In <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> and especially in those with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>, difference in <style="CurrentLink">Skill</style> levels can both encourage <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style> but create problems with <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characteristics">Characteristics</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="determinable-chance-succeed">Determinable Chance to Succeed</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="facilitating-rewards">Facilitating Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Performance%20Modifiers">Performance Modifiers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>
